div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Alton P. Tisdel, August 14, 1940
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
August 14, 1940
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
RECEIVED
SUPERINTENDENT OF DOCUMENTS
AUG
19
1940
Mr. Alton P. Tisdel
Superintendent of Documents
United States Government Printing Office
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Tisdel:
div1.p:
Two years ago, I requested a copy of Senate Document Vol 61,
Number 822, 61st Congress, Third Session, Report of the Yellow Fever Commission.
This I did very blithely, not realizing how rare that volume was. You very
kindly located a copy of this from Mrs. Kidwell (your correspondence of
August 9, and August 17, 1937). I can assure you that I have used this
volume long and well. Originally, I wanted it in connection with the
preparation of an address to be given at Washington and Jefferson College,
Washington, Pennsylvania this Fall, on the occasion of the dedication of a
Lazear Memorial Building, at which time I will present a paper on the conquest
of yellow fever. Since then, I have become greatly interested in this story.
I have visited Kissinger in Huntington, Indiana, and Moran in Havana, two
privates who were the first to volunteer to Walter Reed as subjects for experi-
mental yellow fever. I have also visited General Kean in Washington, and have
had considerable correspondence with General Truby as well as visiting Miss
Agramonte, the daughter of Dr. Agramonte, one of Walter Reed's colleagues.

On my recent visit to Cuba, I found that the government had lost
track of Camp Lazear and had erroneously identified another site where they are
preparing to build a memorial for which already two hundred thousand dollars
have been collected. I was able to find the true site and prove that the site
now selected is wrong. This was only possible by my intimate knowledge of the
Senate Document which you so kindly sent me. The Cuban government has asked
me to send them documentary evidence, etc. so that they may relocate the proper
site. In connection with this report to them, and in my forthcoming talk at
Washington and Jefferson College, I am most anxious to obtain several more
governmental documents, and would appreciate greatly your help in this matter.
They are as follows:
exhausted 1. The Surgeon General's Report for 1901 (I should like four or five
copies if they are available.
exhausted 2. Senate Report No. 574, 61st Congress, Second Session (referred to

I shall of course be delighted to pay whatever expense is involved
in obtaining these documents, and I am anxious to know whether you have an index
listing other documents referring to Walter Reed and the yellow fever experiments
or the volunteers of these experiments.

61-3 If there is any possibility of obtaining one or two more copies of
Senate Document 822, I shall, of course, be delighted to have them, and I wonder
if you know of any second-hand book store in Washington which might specialize
in old governmental publications that might not be available in your office.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
DVP
August 26, 1940
Respectfully returned with the information that the documents
requested are exhausted from stock in all forms. You can no
doubt consult copies of the bound Serials in a large public
library in your vicinity.
